Package DBAccess

Class OrderMapper

  • java.lang.Object
    • DBAccess.OrderMapper
  • public class OrderMapper
extends java.lang.Object
    The purpose of the OrderMapper is to interact with the database and retrieve or alter order information in it through select, insert, update and delete methods.

                     throws LoginSampleException,
                            java.sql.SQLException,
                            java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        The addOrder method is the first part of the final order that is added to the database.
        Parameters:
        customerId - The customer ID is necessary to make an order.
        Throws:
        LoginSampleException - Thrown if login credentials do not match with any of the registered customers in the database.
        java.sql.SQLException - Thrown if the provided SQL string in each method has incorrect syntax, unknown keywords etc.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown from Connector if the "Class.forName" method doesn't find the specified class (JDBC driver in this case).

      • getOrderId

        public static int getOrderId​(int customerId)
                      throws LoginSampleException,
                             java.sql.SQLException,
                             java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        The getOrderId method is specifically made to ensure that order IDs and orderLine IDs are paired correctly when an order is added to the database. This method is necessary because of how the order system works in our database. An order is made first, followed by an orderLine. Both have unique IDs, but an orderLine cannot be made without an order ID. Therefore, after the order is made, this method is called. It then gets all order IDs tied to the customer with the ID provided as an argument, adds them to an ArrayList of Integers and counts the number of elements in the array. When there are no more order IDs to retrieve, the last element added to the ArrayList will be returned. NOTE: the variable 'count' starts at -1 to ensure that it is equal to the index of the final element in the array. When the while loop begins, and the first order is added, it becomes 0 which then matches with the index of the first element in the array.
        Parameters:
        customerId - This customer ID is necessary to make the final order, for reasons explained above.
        Returns:
        When the loop is finished, the final element (the order ID) of the ArrayList is selected with the count variable and returned.
        Throws:
        LoginSampleException - Thrown if login credentials do not match with any of the registered customers in the database.
        java.sql.SQLException - Thrown if the provided SQL string in each method has incorrect syntax, unknown keywords etc.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown from Connector if the "Class.forName" method doesn't find the specified class (JDBC driver in this case).

      • addOrderLine

        public static int addOrderLine​(int orderId,
                               int quantity,
                               int totalPrice,
                               int toppingId,
                               int bottomId)
                        throws LoginSampleException,
                               java.sql.SQLException,
                               java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        the addOrderLine method adds the second part of an order to the database.
        Parameters:
        orderId - This order ID is provided by the getOrderId method.
        quantity - The customer's selected quantity of cupcakes in their order.
        totalPrice - The final price of the customer's order, determined by added the price of the selected bottom and topping and multiplying them with the quantity.
        toppingId - The ID matching the customer's selected topping.
        bottomId - The ID matching the customer's selected bottom.
        Returns:
        The newId variable that this method returns is not used for anything. Could maybe change the method to void return type instead.
        Throws:
        LoginSampleException - Thrown if login credentials do not match with any of the registered customers in the database.
        java.sql.SQLException - Thrown if the provided SQL string in each method has incorrect syntax, unknown keywords etc.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown from Connector if the "Class.forName" method doesn't find the specified class (JDBC driver in this case).

      • countOrdersById

        public static int countOrdersById​(int customerId)
                           throws LoginSampleException,
                                  java.sql.SQLException,
                                  java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        the countOrdersById method is exclusively used for the admin's customer page where all customers in the database can be seen. It's sole purpose is to show how many orders the individual customer has made.
        Parameters:
        customerId - Since the orders are counted for each customer, a customer ID is necessary to find the number of orders tied to the customer.
        Returns:
        The variable 'count' is returned, which is equal to the number of rows found in the database with the SQL string.
        Throws:
        LoginSampleException - Thrown if login credentials do not match with any of the registered customers in the database.
        java.sql.SQLException - Thrown if the provided SQL string in each method has incorrect syntax, unknown keywords etc.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown from Connector if the "Class.forName" method doesn't find the specified class (JDBC driver in this case).

      • getSpecificOrders

        public static java.util.ArrayList<Order> getSpecificOrders​(int id)
                                                    throws LoginSampleException,
                                                           java.sql.SQLException,
                                                           java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        the getSpecificOrders method is used when the admin wishes to see all orders made by a specific customer on the admin order page.
        Parameters:
        id - The ID of the customer whose orders the admin wants to see.
        Returns:
        All of the orders retrieved are added to an ArrayList and returned so they can be displayed on the admin order page.
        Throws:
        LoginSampleException - Thrown if login credentials do not match with any of the registered customers in the database.
        java.sql.SQLException - Thrown if the provided SQL string in each method has incorrect syntax, unknown keywords etc.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown from Connector if the "Class.forName" method doesn't find the specified class (JDBC driver in this case).

      • getCustomerOrders

        public static java.util.ArrayList<Order> getCustomerOrders​(int customerId)
                                                    throws LoginSampleException,
                                                           java.sql.SQLException,
                                                           java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        the getCustomerOrders method is used for customers who want to see their own registered orders.
        Parameters:
        customerId - Used to make sure the correct orders are retrieved.
        Returns:
        All orders are added to an ArrayList and returned so they can be displayed on the customer's "myorders" page.
        Throws:
        LoginSampleException - Thrown if login credentials do not match with any of the registered customers in the database.
        java.sql.SQLException - Thrown if the provided SQL string in each method has incorrect syntax, unknown keywords etc.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown from Connector if the "Class.forName" method doesn't find the specified class (JDBC driver in this case).
